title: 113_hr5070
content:
The Act is titled the "Earnings Advancement and Recovery Now Act" or the "EARN Act". EITC compliance savings will be dedicated to expanding the EITC. The Congress finds that the Treasury Inspector General's report highlighted significant improper payments related to the earned income tax credit. The Internal Revenue Service estimates that 22-26% of EITC payments were issued improperly in fiscal year 2013. The Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration reported significant improper payments related to the earned income tax credit, estimating between $13.3 billion and $15.6 billion in fiscal year 2013. The Internal Revenue Service has made little improvement in reducing these improper payments, with the earned income tax credit program remaining at high risk. The Joint Committee on Taxation estimates 28.5 million filers will receive the credit in tax year 2014, highlighting the need for reforms to prevent billions of dollars in improper payments. The earned income tax credit program has significant improper payments, estimated at $13.3 billion to $15.6 billion in fiscal year 2013. Reforms are needed to prevent billions of dollars in improper payments, with any budgetary savings dedicated to expanding the credit for eligible working families. SEC. 3. Increase penalty for tax preparers engaging in willful or reckless conduct to 75 percent. Effective for returns prepared after enactment of this Act.

SEC. 4. Extend disallowance period for taxpayers improperly claiming EITC based on reckless or intentional disregard of rules to 5 taxable years. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2013. SEC. 5. Expansion of math-error authority to cover EITC claims during period when taxpayer is barred from claiming the credit. Amendment applies to taxable years ending after enactment of this Act. 

SEC. 6. Penalty for erroneous claim of credit made applicable to Earned Income Credit. Amendment applies to claims filed after enactment of this Act. 

SEC. 7. Study on Earned Income Credit and improper payments. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the effectiveness and impact of the earned income tax credit and the causes of improper payments by the IRS. Recommendations will be made to improve the credit's efficiency and reduce improper payments. A report will be submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Senate Finance Committee will receive a report with study results and recommendations on the earned income tax credit within 6 months of the Act's enactment.
